instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND: What is PP2V5_NAND? PP2V5_NAND is a power rail that powers the NAND memory for the soldered on SSD of newer macbooks and must be present for the internal SSD to work. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sort in <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi, 

I got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with a short in <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>. I know its a night mare but wanted to try. Also I have the donor parts so first removed <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> Still 2.5 ohm on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>. Then removed <CHIP>U8700</CHIP> and the short was gone. So wanted to only replace these two nand chips but read that you have to change all 4 as a set. So removed <CHIP>U8800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> to. Checked if <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL> is there but still nothing after shirt was gone. 

Figured out that PP2v5 is not being created beacause <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> was dead. Replaced it and all SSD/Nand power lines came active. Got the NAND chips from my donor and after reballing and cleaning everything. Got the chips on the exact same order back on my board. (had to do one 3 times because when I placed it I got a short!?!, figured out I had my schematic upside down (felt MEGA stupid, wasted 2 hours)) 

Now I know I have to restore T2 data. First DFU mode attempt failed. Board stuck at 20v, 0,046a. Second attempt again failed but board was almost booting. 20v, 0,6amp. Looks like I'm almost there. Fan spin and cpuvcore is 0,825V But does not go down. Stays at 0,825V This means not booting. Can someone Help? 

I was thinking something of bios? It doesn't boot... And how can I be shore NAND is correctly placed?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sort in <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
The BIOS is embedded on the T2.
It is reflashed in the DFU process.

So much heat applied repeatedly on the same NAND may not be too good.
You are not sure about chips quality now; even they have been soldered in correct order.
Try another NAND kit...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sort in <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Great tip, also this is the first time im changing NAND chip with underfill. Nightmare of a job... I have another donor here so will try that!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sort in <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>
threads.message: How much heat and air do you suggest to get NAND chips off? They are underfilled, very hard job.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> sort in <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Depends on your hot air station.
Many videos available on Internet; practice on scrap boards.
